reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “product of factors”/multiplicative model that supports the intuition that near-best futures are intrinsically fragile and rare. That model is an important pillar of Section 2 (and appears in Forethought’s broader EV decomposition style), but it is not the paper’s whole case: much of Section 2 is an existence-of-single-big-flaws argument, and Section 3’s “most plausible moral views are fussy” analysis is largely independent of literal multiplicativity. So centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The critique’s argumentative strength is limited: it asserts that many moral theories are additive/threshold/substitutable and that dimensions are correlated, but it doesn’t (i) show that plausible ‘easygoing liberalism’ or other candidate views actually yield a wide basin of mostly-great futures under Forethought’s conditional distribution, (ii) engage the paper’s explicit point that multiplicativity is a toy model meant to capture complementarity/fragility rather than a strict axiom, or (iii) address the Section 3 reasons for fussiness under many bounded/unbounded value functions. Relevance is moderate because this is a Tier-2 style challenge to a modeling move Forethought uses across “Better Futures” work, but it’s not clearly a Tier-3 open question and the critique doesn’t add novel technical alternatives or evidence.
title: "Multiplicative model assumption undermines 'fragility' conclusion"
